Dialog:
Patient: I've been experiencing a stiff neck for a few days now, and it's becoming quite painful. What should I do?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing a stiff neck and pain. To better understand your situation, did the pain start within the past 24 hours?
Next Protocol: Did the pain start within the past 24 hours?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're in pain. Do you have any numbness or tingling in your arm or hand? Also, are you over the age of 50?
Previous Protocol: Has the pain or stiffness been getting worse for several months?
Next Protocol: Do you have numbness or tingling in your arm or hand, or are you over age 50?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: Given your symptoms and age, it's important to see your doctor. You may have a disorder of the joints in your neck or a nerve issue, such as carpal tunnel syndrome. Please seek medical attention for a proper evaluation.
Previous Protocol: Do you have numbness or tingling in your arm or hand, or are you over age 50?
Next Protocol: See your doctor. You may have a disorder of the joints in the neck. Or you may have a nerve disorder such as carpal tunnel syndrome.

Dialog:
Patient: My daughter has been complaining of tummy pain near her belly button for the past two days. What should we do?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that your daughter is in pain. Does even the slightest movement seem to hurt so much that she screams with pain? This information will help determine the next steps.
Next Protocol: Does even the slightest movement seem to hurt so much that your child screams with pain?

Dialog:
Patient: No, she hasn't eaten anything unusual or spicy recently. Her diet has been pretty normal, and I haven't noticed any overeating. She's been eating her regular meals without any changes.
TriageMD: Has your daughter had three to four watery bowel movements within the last 24 hours or experienced any vomiting? This information can help determine the next steps.
Previous Protocol: Has your child overeaten or eaten anything (such as a spicy food) that could have upset his or her stomach?
Next Protocol: Has your child had three to four watery bowel movements within 24 hours or been vomiting?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: It's common for children to experience abdominal pain when they have a cold or respiratory infection, as swallowing mucus can upset the stomach. Since she has a runny nose and is feeling uncomfortable, this could be contributing to her tummy pain. Keep an eye on her symptoms, and if her pain worsens, or if you have any concerns, it would be best to consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation.
Previous Protocol: Does your child have a runny nose or a sore throat?
Next Protocol: Children often have abdominal pain when they have a cold or other respiratory infection because they swallow mucus, which can upset the stomach.

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: I've been experiencing sharp, intermittent pain around my left eye for the past two days. It's becoming quite bothersome.
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear you're experiencing pain around your left eye. Did you injure your eye in any way?
Next Protocol: Did you injure your eye?

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: Does the pain seem to come from behind your eye?
Previous Protocol: Is your eyeball or eyelid red?
Next Protocol: Does the pain seem to come from behind your eye?

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: Given your symptoms, it's important to consult with your doctor for a proper evaluation. They can help determine the cause of your pain and recommend appropriate treatment. Take care.
Previous Protocol: Is there an area of tenderness over your nose or in your cheekbones?
Next Protocol: See your doctor if you are unable to make a decision from self-triage.

Dialog:
Patient: I'm having trouble finding the right words when I speak, and it's becoming quite frustrating. Can someone help me understand what's happening?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. To better understand your situation, could you let me know if you've experienced any of the following symptoms: dizziness, headache, weakness in your arms or legs, numbness or tingling in any part of your body, blurred vision, or difficulty swallowing?
Next Protocol: Have you had one or more of the following symptoms: dizziness; headache; weakness in your arms or legs; numbness or tingling in any part of your body; blurred vision; difficulty swallowing?

Dialog:
Patient: No, I'm not taking any medication at the moment. I haven't started any new treatments or changed anything recently, so I don't think that's related to the issues I'm experiencing with finding the right words.
TriageMD: Is it difficult to speak because you are unable to move the muscles on one side of your face?
Previous Protocol: Are you taking any medication?
Next Protocol: Is it difficult to speak because you are unable to move the muscles on one side of your face?I

Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: It sounds like you're experiencing some challenges with your speech, which can be frustrating. I recommend seeing your doctor to discuss your symptoms further. They can help determine the underlying cause and provide appropriate support.
Previous Protocol: Are you sometimes unable to speak even though you know what you want to say, or do you sometimes get stuck at the beginning of a word and find yourself repeating the first consonant for several seconds before you can say the entire word?
Next Protocol: See your doctor if you are unable to make a decision from self-triage.

Dialog:
Patient: Lately, I'm having trouble remembering where I put things and sometimes forget what day it is. Should I be worried?
TriageMD: I understand that you're feeling concerned about your memory and confusion. Have you been experiencing these feelings only recently?
Next Protocol: Have you been feeling confused only recently?

Dialog:
Patient: No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms like a fever, coughing, or bladder control issues. It's mainly just the memory and organization problems that have been bothering me. I feel physically fine otherwise, which is why I'm not sure what's causing these memory lapses.
TriageMD: It's good to hear that you feel physically fine otherwise. Do you feel very cold or chilled, or does your abdomen feel unusually cold?
Previous Protocol: Is the confusion accompanied by signs of illness such as a fever, coughing, or lack of bladder control?
Next Protocol: Do you feel very cold or chilled, or does your abdomen feel unusually cold?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: It's important to have something to eat or drink, especially if you have a condition like diabetes. If your confusion persists, please see your doctor for further evaluation. Take care of yourself!
Previous Protocol: Have you gone without eating for some time?
Next Protocol: Have something to eat or drink, especially if you have a condition such as diabetes. See your doctor if the confusion persists.

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: My daughter has been complaining of pain in her right ear for the past two days. What should we do?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that your daughter is in pain. To help assess her condition, could you please let me know if the pain gets worse when you pull down on her earlobe?
Next Protocol: Does the pain get worse when you pull down on your earlobe?

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: Does the affected ear have a sticky yellow discharge?
Previous Protocol: Do you have a blocked-up feeling in your ear that cannot be cleared by swallowing?
Next Protocol: Does the affected ear have a sticky yellow discharge?

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: It's common for earaches to occur with colds, especially when they involve the upper respiratory tract. These usually subside as the cold clears up. However, if the pain becomes severe, it's important to see your doctor, as you could have a middle ear infection. Take care!
Previous Protocol: Do you have a cold?
Next Protocol: See your doctor if the pain is severe; you could have a middle ear infection. Earaches are a common symptom of colds that involve the upper respiratory tract, and usually subside when the cold clears up.

Dialog:
Patient: My daughter has been vomiting for a week now and I'm really worried. What should I do?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that your daughter has been vomiting for a week. Can you confirm if she has been having episodes of vomiting for that entire time?
Next Protocol: Have you been having episodes of vomiting for a week or longer?

Dialog:
Patient: No, she doesn't have severe abdominal pain that lasts for an hour or more. She has mentioned feeling uncomfortable or having mild pain, but it doesn't seem to be constant or very intense. I'm more concerned about the vomiting itself because it's been going on for several days now, and I'm not sure what could be causing it.
TriageMD: I understand your concern. Has she vomited blood or any black or dark brown matter that looks like coffee grounds?
Previous Protocol: Do you have severe abdominal pain that has lasted at least 1 hour and has not been relieved by vomiting?
Next Protocol: Have you vomited blood, or black or dark brown matter that looks like coffee grounds (partially digested blood)?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: EMERGENCY: Get medical help now! Call 911 or your local emergency number, or have someone take you to the nearest hospital emergency department. The presence of dark vomit could indicate internal bleeding, which requires immediate attention. Please act quickly.
Previous Protocol: Have you vomited blood, or black or dark brown matter that looks like coffee grounds (partially digested blood)?
Next Protocol: EMERGENCY: Get medical help now! Call 911 or your local emergency number or have someone take you to the nearest hospital emergency department. You probably have internal bleeding, possibly from a peptic ulcer or another condition in the digestive tract.

Dialog:
Patient: I've been acting out of character lately and it's starting to worry me. Can you help figure out what's going on?
TriageMD: I understand that you're feeling worried about your recent behavior. Can you tell me if you've been feeling confused about time, places, or events? This information can help us understand what's going on.
Next Protocol: Does the person seem confused about time, places, or events?

Dialog:
Patient: No, it's not just brief or intermittent. It feels more consistent, like a shift in my usual behavior. I can't really pinpoint when it started, but it's been noticeable for a while now. It's like I'm not acting like myself, and it's affecting how I interact with others and handle situations.
TriageMD: It sounds like you're experiencing a significant change in your behavior. Are you finding yourself preoccupied with a single idea or activity more than usual?
Previous Protocol: Does the person behave normally most of the time and behave strangely only for brief, intermittent periods?
Next Protocol: Does the person seem preoccupied with a single idea or activity?"

Dialog:
Patient: No, I wouldn't say I'm feeling unusually restless or having trouble concentrating. I can still focus on my tasks and relax when I need to. It's more about how I'm interacting with others and how I handle situations. My reactions just seem different, and I'm not sure why.
TriageMD: I understand that this is concerning for you. Given the changes in your behavior and interactions, it's important to seek medical attention. I recommend that you see a doctor as soon as possible to discuss your symptoms. There could be underlying issues that need to be addressed, including the possibility of something like a brain tumor. Please take care of yourself and seek help promptly.
Previous Protocol: Does the person seem unusually restless and unable to relax or concentrate on his or her usual activities?
Next Protocol: Take the person to a doctor immediately if you are unable to make a decision from self-triage. There is a chance that a brain tumor could be causing the person's unusual behavior.

Dialog:
Patient: I've been experiencing swelling and pain in my right foot for the past week. What could be causing this?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear about your swelling and pain. Have you injured your foot within the past 24 hours?
Next Protocol: Have you injured your foot within the past 24 hours?

Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: Did the pain start after walking or running?
Previous Protocol: Do both feet ache all over?
Next Protocol: Did the pain start after walking or running?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: It's important that you see your doctor. You may have broken a small bone in your foot, or you could have a swollen nerve that rubs between two bones when you walk or run. If the pain in your foot disappears promptly when you stop walking, it could indicate a circulatory disorder such as atherosclerosis. Please seek medical attention for a proper evaluation.
Previous Protocol: Did the pain start after walking or running?
Next Protocol: See your doctor. You may have broken a small bone in your foot. Or you may have a swollen nerve that rubs between two bones when you walk or run. However, if you have pain in the foot when you walk that disappears promptly when you stop, you may have a circulatory disorder such as atherosclerosis.

Dialog:
Patient: I've been hearing voices that aren't there, and it's starting to really scare me. What should I do?
TriageMD: I'm really sorry to hear that you're experiencing this. It's important to address these symptoms. Do you have any of the following: general confusion about time, places, or events; agitated behavior; or signs of physical illness?
Next Protocol: Do you have one or more of the following symptoms: general confusion about time, places, or events; agitated behavior; signs of physical illness?

Dialog:
Patient: No, the voices aren't related to sleep. They happen at different times throughout the day, and it feels like they're coming from outside of me, like someone is actually talking to me, but no one is there. It's really unsettling.
TriageMD: I understand how unsettling that must be for you. Can I ask if you drink a lot of alcohol or use illegal drugs?
Previous Protocol: Do the hallucinations occur only just before you fall asleep or just after you wake up?
Next Protocol: Do you drink a lot of alcohol, or do you use illegal drugs?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes, actually, now that you mention it, I have sometimes thought I heard my grandmother's voice. She passed away a few years ago, and occasionally I feel like I hear her calling my name or saying something she used to say. It's kind of comforting in a way, but also a bit confusing since I know she's not really there.
TriageMD: It's understandable to feel both comforted and confused by hearing your grandmother's voice, especially after her passing. This type of experience can sometimes occur as part of the grieving process. I recommend discussing this with your doctor, as they can provide support and guidance.
Previous Protocol: Did you think that you saw or heard a close relative or friend who died recently?
Next Protocol: Talk to your doctor, although this type of hallucination often occurs as part of the grieving process.
